conclusion: Determine the length L_n of the n-th metal cylinder and the velocity v_1 of the electron as it enters cylinder 1.
Analyze the motion of the electron from the moment it starts moving from the circular plate until it exits cylinder 2.
The work done by the electric field on the electron is equal to the kinetic energy gained by the electron: eU = 1/2 m v_1^2.
Solving for v_1 gives v_1 = sqrt(2eU/m).
The electron enters cylinder 1 with velocity v_1. Inside cylinder 1, there is no electric field, so the electron travels with constant velocity v_1.
After exiting cylinder 1, the electron enters the gap between cylinder 1 and cylinder 2.
At this point, the potential difference between cylinder 1 and cylinder 2 is -U (since the polarity of the AC power supply has reversed).
The electron is again accelerated by the electric field in the gap between cylinder 1 and cylinder 2.
The work done by the electric field in the gap between cylinder 1 and cylinder 2 is eU = 1/2 m v_2^2 - 1/2 m v_1^2.
Simplifying gives 2eU = 1/2 m v_2^2, leading to v_2 = sqrt(4eU/m) = 2 sqrt(2eU/m) = 2v_1.
Inside cylinder 2, the electron travels with constant velocity v_2.
The time for the electron to pass through the n-th cylinder is T/2 because the polarity of the AC power supply changes every T/2.
The length L_n of the n-th cylinder is given by L_n = v_n * T/2.
From the previous analysis, the velocity v_n of the electron as it enters the n-th cylinder is v_n = n sqrt(2eU/m).
Thus, the length L_n of the n-th cylinder is L_n = n sqrt(2eU/m) * T/2 = nT/2 sqrt(2eU/m).
The length L_n of the n-th metal cylinder is boxed{nT/2 sqrt(2eU/m)}.
